initial_sentence: I feel a constant need to meet others' expectations to avoid frustration or disappointment, both personally and professionally.

chat_history.content: I feel a constant need to meet others' expectations to avoid frustration or disappointment, both personally and professionally.

He raised an eyebrow, amused by your response. “Expectations, huh?”

He leaned forward a little, resting his chin on his hand. “Why do you care what others think? You know that stuff’s just a bunch of made-up bullshit, right?”

Yeah, I know it's not logical, but it feels like if I don't meet those expectations, I'll somehow prove I'm incompetent or a failure. It's hard to shake off the need to feel in control, like I'm always being measured against some invisible standard. Sometimes, I wish I didn't care so much, but it's like those thoughts won't let go.

He hummed thoughtfully, sipping his drink. “That sounds exhausting. Constantly worrying about what other people think.”

He chuckled softly. “I wouldn’t know anything about it. I stopped giving a damn about expectations a long time ago.”

It is exhausting; it's like there's this constant pressure looming over me. I mean, I wish I could just let go and not care, like you seem to do. But, for me, the fear of not being good enough just feels so real and hard to ignore.

He watched you with a gaze that felt like it pierced right through you. “Good enough for who, though? Why the need to please?”

He shook his head, swirling the ice in his glass. “You’re worrying about all the wrong things, doll.”

I guess it's mostly about being good enough for people around me, like my colleagues or even my dad. There's this belief that if I don't meet their expectations, it confirms all those fears about being a failure. I know I shouldn’t let it control me, but it just... it feels like I’m stuck in this cycle.

He narrowed his eyes, studying you closely. “And what about being good enough for yourself?”

He took another sip of his drink, his gaze never leaving you. “You’re so preoccupied with pleasing everyone else. When do you get to just be yourself?”

Honestly, I'm not sure I know what being 'myself' looks like anymore. It's like I'm always trying to measure up to what others expect, without really thinking about what I want or need. Sometimes, I wonder if I'd even recognize what being good enough for myself feels like.

He leaned back, a smirk playing at his lips. “That sounds like a pretty empty existence, doll. Letting other people dictate your life.”

He drummed his fingers on the bar, his gaze never leaving yours. “You ever consider just saying 'no'? Doing what YOU want for a change?”

It does feel empty at times, like I'm just going through the motions for everyone else. Saying 'no' seems simple, yet it's terrifying—I feel like if I let people down, it’ll just prove I'm incompetent. But, maybe it's something I need to try more often, for my own sake.

He chuckled softly, a hint of mockery in his voice. “You’re so afraid of a little bit of disappointment, you’ll go your whole life never doing what YOU want?”

He leaned forward, his gaze intense. “What about your happiness? Doesn’t that count for anything?”

I know it sounds ridiculous, being so afraid of disappointment that I lose sight of my own happiness. Truth is, I've never really considered my own desires as much as I probably should. Maybe I'm scared that if I focus on what I want, I won't have the support to make it happen.

He rolled his eyes, shaking his head slightly. “That’s a whole lotta self-pity right there, doll. You think you’re the only one who’s scared? You think anyone else has it easy?”

He took another sip of his drink, watching you closely. “You gotta stop doubting yourself. Take a damn risk, for once in your life.”

I guess you're right. It's just hard to break free from the pattern of doubting myself all the time. But maybe, taking a risk is the only way I’ll learn if I can rely on myself and find out what truly makes me happy.

Hi, um, I've been having these nightmares... They're about being completely unprepared for some big presentation—like a thesis defense. It's not just the dreams that bother me; I'm really worried that people at work might think I'm incompetent. That makes it hard for me to relax or trust that I'm doing a good job.

He raised an eyebrow, his expression softening slightly. "Nightmares, huh? Sounds like you're putting a lot of pressure on yourself."

He took another sip of his drink. "You realize you're making yourself miserable, right? And for what? To impress some people at work?"

I know it sounds irrational, but it's hard to shake the feeling that if I don't keep up, I'll fall behind and fail. I can't help but think that if people at work are disappointed, it confirms those fears I have about being incompetent. But yeah, I do struggle with the pressure I put on myself and sometimes it feels like I'm just stuck in this cycle.

He shook his head, his expression a mix of mockery and disbelief. "You’re living your life for other people, doll. You realize that, right?"

He leaned forward slightly, his gaze intense. "You've gotta start putting yourself first. You’re the one who has to live in your own damn skin."

I know you're right, and part of me really wants to make that change. It’s just overwhelming to think about prioritizing myself when those feelings of inadequacy and fear of letting others down are so strong. But maybe it’s time I started figuring out how to make myself a priority.

He rolled his eyes, a hint of frustration in his voice. "Damnit, doll. You keep coming back to the same thing. You worry too damn much about what everyone else thinks."

He took another sip of his drink. "You know what your problem is? You're a people pleaser. You always put other people's needs before yours."

I can't deny that—I do have a tendency to put others before myself, as if I've got this deep-rooted need to make sure everyone else is okay. It's like I think that if I don't keep everyone else satisfied, it somehow reflects my failure or incompetence. I see your point, and maybe that realization is a step toward finding some balance in my life.
